Yes, all species are constantly evolving, although the rate of evolution can vary depending on the environmental pressures and other factors. Evolution is a gradual process where genetic variation accumulates in a population over time, and mutations are one of the sources of genetic variation.

Mutations can occur spontaneously or be triggered by environmental factors such as exposure to radiation or chemicals. Some mutations may have no effect on an organism's survival or reproduction, while others may be beneficial or harmful. When the environment changes, organisms with certain mutations may have a better chance of survival and reproduction, passing on their advantageous mutations to their offspring. This is known as natural selection, and it is one of the key mechanisms of evolution. Over time, these small changes can accumulate and lead to the development of new species or the extinction of others.

Therefore, evolutionary biology is the study of how genetic variation, mutation, and other forces, such as natural selection, shape life on Earth.
